The Sprue is the vertical part of the running system that in sand casting typically connects the pouring basin at the top with further parts of the running system. It is crucial to correctly design this element to avoid situations where the sprue is either too tapered, increasing metal velocity at the bottom or not tapered enough allowing the liquid metal to fall turbulently. Both cases can potentially introduce defects in the system.

 	This calculator allows you to calculate the correct dimensions of the sprue based on it's height and either the top or bottom size. Optionally you can set the required volumetric flow rate of the metal with the sprue height (feature to be implemented).

 	The Safety Factor is the percentage value introduced to compensate for any potential flow losses in the initial stages of the system. Positive values of the Safety Factor increase the taper, choking the metal flow and therefore preventing any potential turbulent flow. The default value is 20%

\tRunner bar is the part of the running system that distributes the liquid metal from sprue and well into the in-gates connected to the casting. There are two main approaches to designing good runner bar. One is to constrain the metal flow to decrease the space where turbulent flow can occur. This approach is commonly paired with l-shape sprue-runner junction design or similar constrained design. In this design the runner bar is usually slightly pressurized or neutral (see summary tab to check your design ratios). The other approach is to have a significantly bigger sprue-runner bar area ratio (around 1:4) to slow down the liquid metal below turbulent velocity (0.5m/s). This design is usually paired with filters directly after the sprue.\n\n \t Setup an values plugged in this tab are used for calculating the system ratio and metal yield that can be found in the summary tab.

This calculator allows you to optimise the sprue - runner junction for optimal flow utilising the L-shape design. This geometry allows for the least obstructive fluid flow while at the same time reducing turbulence caused by rapid flow direction change and high velocity. This shape also considers reasonable mouldability constrains.\n\n The main part of the design is the minimum smooth transition radius at the junction, calculated based on the metal velocity and main sprue dimensions. This geometry is often paired with filters placed directly under the ingates to prevent formation of high velocity metal jets when the metal is required to rapidly change flow direction to fill the ingates.

This app was developed with foundry engineers in mind (professional and home-grown) looking to speed up their design process when developing new systems and calculating design properties. Please be aware that some of the calculations base on approximations and every foundry uses different approach to system design, therefore results may differ from those tailor made for your foundry. I do not take responsibility for decisions taken by the reader based solely on the information provided in this app. 

Version: 0.1 
This is the first release of this app and it may still contain bugs and errors, so feel free to let me know if you encounter any problems or have a suggestion for improvement. 
As of now, the project saves do not store the values for feeders. Please bear that in mind when working with loaded project and want to analyze the yield od fill time.

I am a foundry engineer working professionally with light weight alloys in defense and airspace industry. I am learning programming and this engineering calculator is the first app that I developed. I wanted to develop a tool that I could also use in my professional career and I hope that someone else might also find it useful. If you would like to share your thoughts on this app please feel free to write to \nrafal.m.urbanek@gmail.com
